issue.title: Cannot disable Thrift protocol
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Cannot disable Thrift protocol

**To Reproduce**
Call capture = pyshark.FileCapture(nombre_fich,display_filter=filter_str,disable_protocol='Thrift',include_raw=True, use_json=True)
**Expected behavior**
Remove Thrift packets and treat them as UDP

**Versions (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows
 - pyshark version: 0.5.3
 - tshark version:

**Example pcap / packet**

forkee.name: pyshark
forkee.description: Python wrapper for tshark, allowing python packet parsing using wireshark dissectors

issue.title: data._all_fields is not working with use_ek
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
startswith is called on dict

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\Yaroslav\Documents\data_bot\parser-cap.py", line 116, in <module>
    if ("tls.reassembled.data" in x.data._all_fields):
  File "C:\Python310\lib\site-packages\pyshark\packet\layers\base.py", line 46, in __getattr__
    val = self.get_field(item)
  File "C:\Python310\lib\site-packages\pyshark\packet\layers\ek_layer.py", line 54, in get_field
    nested_field = self._get_nested_field(prefix, name)
  File "C:\Python310\lib\site-packages\pyshark\packet\layers\ek_layer.py", line 98, in _get_nested_field
    if possible_nested_name.startswith(f"{field_ek_name}_"):
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'startswith'
```

**To Reproduce**
```
cap = pyshark.FileCapture('data.pcapng', display_filter="websocket and ip.src != 192.168.0.0/16", include_raw=True, use_ek=True)

for x in cap:
  if 'DATA' in x:
    if "tls.reassembled.data" in x.data._all_fields:
      pass
```

**Expected behavior**
Same behavior as with XML packet version

**Versions (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows
 - pyshark version: 0.6
 - tshark version: 4.0.6

issue.title: `apply_on_packets` not terminating after `packet_count`
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When using `apply_on_packets` with `packet_count` specified, the capture does not terminate despite the packet count being met. Setting the `timeout` together with the `packet_count` parameter does not terminate the capture either. (`timeout` parameter works well on its own when `packet_count` is not specified)

This is my debug log:

```
2023-09-27 11:24:51,283 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Creating Dumpcap subprocess with parameters: /usr/bin/dumpcap -q -i enp0s8 -w -
2023-09-27 11:24:51,288 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Dumpcap subprocess (pid 35040) created
2023-09-27 11:24:51,584 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Creating TShark subprocess with parameters: /usr/bin/tshark -l -n -T pdml -c 5  -w /tmp/mitm-output.pcap -i -
2023-09-27 11:24:51,585 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Executable: /usr/bin/tshark
2023-09-27 11:24:51,588 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Capturing on 'enp0s8'
2023-09-27 11:24:51,589 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - File: -
2023-09-27 11:24:51,590 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - TShark subprocess (pid 35059) created
2023-09-27 11:24:51,590 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Starting to go through packets
2023-09-27 11:24:51,623 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Running as user "root" and group "root". This could be dangerous.
2023-09-27 11:24:51,922 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Capturing on '-'
2023-09-27 11:24:51,937 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - ** (tshark:35059) 11:24:51.935238 [Main MESSAGE] -- Capture started.
2023-09-27 11:24:51,938 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - ** (tshark:35059) 11:24:51.935277 [Main MESSAGE] -- File: "/tmp/mitm-output.pcap"
2023-09-27 11:24:52,238 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Cleanup Subprocess (pid 35059)
2023-09-27 11:24:52,240 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - 5 packets captured
Unknown child process pid 35059, will report returncode 255
2023-09-27 11:24:52,246 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Cleanup Subprocess (pid 35040)
```

My guess is that the underlying tshark process is being terminated before pyshark is able to perform any cleanups. This results in the event loop failing to terminate properly and continuously resets itself.

**To Reproduce**
Simply create a python3 script that uses `LiveCapture` and use `apply_on_packets`.

```python3
capture = pyshark.LiveCapture(
        interface="enp0s8",
        output_file="/tmp/mitm-output.pcap",
        debug=True,
    )

capture.apply_on_packets(
        lambda packet : print(packet),
        timeout=5,
        packet_count=5,
    )
```

**Expected behavior**
I expect the capture to automatically terminate once the packet count has been reached. It can gracefully stop or raise an exception just like how a `TimeoutError` is raised once the time is up. Either ways, the capture should stop.

**Versions (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: ubuntu@22.04
 - pyshark version: 0.6
 - python version: 3.7.9
 - tshark version: 3.6.2 (Git v3.6.2 packaged as 3.6.2-2)

issue.title: `apply_on_packets` not terminating after `packet_count`
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When using `apply_on_packets` with `packet_count` specified, the capture does not terminate despite the packet count being met. Setting the `timeout` together with the `packet_count` parameter does not terminate the capture either. (`timeout` parameter works well on its own when `packet_count` is not specified)

This is my debug log:

```
2023-09-27 11:24:51,283 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Creating Dumpcap subprocess with parameters: /usr/bin/dumpcap -q -i enp0s8 -w -
2023-09-27 11:24:51,288 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Dumpcap subprocess (pid 35040) created
2023-09-27 11:24:51,584 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Creating TShark subprocess with parameters: /usr/bin/tshark -l -n -T pdml -c 5  -w /tmp/mitm-output.pcap -i -
2023-09-27 11:24:51,585 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Executable: /usr/bin/tshark
2023-09-27 11:24:51,588 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Capturing on 'enp0s8'
2023-09-27 11:24:51,589 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - File: -
2023-09-27 11:24:51,590 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - TShark subprocess (pid 35059) created
2023-09-27 11:24:51,590 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Starting to go through packets
2023-09-27 11:24:51,623 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Running as user "root" and group "root". This could be dangerous.
2023-09-27 11:24:51,922 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Capturing on '-'
2023-09-27 11:24:51,937 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - ** (tshark:35059) 11:24:51.935238 [Main MESSAGE] -- Capture started.
2023-09-27 11:24:51,938 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - ** (tshark:35059) 11:24:51.935277 [Main MESSAGE] -- File: "/tmp/mitm-output.pcap"
2023-09-27 11:24:52,238 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Cleanup Subprocess (pid 35059)
2023-09-27 11:24:52,240 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - 5 packets captured
Unknown child process pid 35059, will report returncode 255
2023-09-27 11:24:52,246 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Cleanup Subprocess (pid 35040)
```

My guess is that the underlying tshark process is being terminated before pyshark is able to perform any cleanups. This results in the event loop failing to terminate properly and continuously resets itself.

**To Reproduce**
Simply create a python3 script that uses `LiveCapture` and use `apply_on_packets`.

```python3
capture = pyshark.LiveCapture(
        interface="enp0s8",
        output_file="/tmp/mitm-output.pcap",
        debug=True,
    )

capture.apply_on_packets(
        lambda packet : print(packet),
        timeout=5,
        packet_count=5,
    )
```

**Expected behavior**
I expect the capture to automatically terminate once the packet count has been reached. It can gracefully stop or raise an exception just like how a `TimeoutError` is raised once the time is up. Either ways, the capture should stop.

**Versions (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: ubuntu@22.04
 - pyshark version: 0.6
 - python version: 3.7.9
 - tshark version: 3.6.2 (Git v3.6.2 packaged as 3.6.2-2)

comment.body:
Apologies, I have made a wrong conclusion on the error logs. The real error was because I wrapped the above code in a `while True` loop. This forced my program to repeatedly start a new capture. Removing the loop fixed the issue.

An area of improvement would be to remove the log message indicating that the underlying tshark process could not be found. It is a potential area of confusion and might lead others in the future to wrongly interpret the logs.

pull_request.title: Fix issue #648 which setting only_summaries to True lead to a bug
pull_request.body: As my comment in the issue #648 , modify the condition is helpful to the bug when setting `only_summaries` to `True`. The same bug was rise in the issue #250 ,issue #604 , etc.

issue.title: Capture File only_summaries=True consistently yields a single packet despite multiple packets
issue.body:
I have tried using `only_summaries=True` on three separate capture files both in PyCharm and Jupyter. Each time, the ingest only yields a single packet as a result. However, omitting the `only_summaries=True` argument yields all of the packets.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Load the pcap with `only_summaries=True`. I have attached the pcap as hex below.

**Expected behavior**
857 frames available in the capture object. However, when 'only_summaries=True` is used, only a single frame is yielded.

**Versions (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: OSX MacBook Pro
 - pyshark version: 0.5.3
 - tshark version: TShark (Wireshark) 4.0.2 (v4.0.2-0-g415456d13370).

**Example pcap / packet**
If applicable, add an example pcap file as an attachment, or post the packet as a hex string or a JSON/XML (export packet dissection in wireshark/tshark).

[ssh_tty.txt](https://github.com/KimiNewt/pyshark/files/11130138/ssh_tty.txt)

comment.body:
I also encountered this problem. After some effort I found the bug is located in line 25 of the file `src/pyshark/tshark/output_parser/tshark_xml.py`. Following is the method.
```python
async def get_packets_from_stream(self, stream, existing_data, got_first_packet=True):
    if self._parse_summaries:
        existing_data = await self._get_psml_struct(stream)
    return await super().get_packets_from_stream(stream, existing_data, got_first_packet=got_first_packet)
```
The buggy code is `if self._parse_summaries:`.
When the first time we called the `get_packets_from_stream` method, there was not enough XML data to create a packet. We will call the `get_packets_from_stream` method again, then we will call the `_get_psml_struct` method again because the `self._parse_summaries` variable is `True`. This time calling the `_get_psml_struct` method will discard existing data and set the `existing_data` variable to the remaining bytestring so a packet will be created which is the only packet you got. The third time we call the `get_packets_from_stream` method will got the `EOFError` and the parsing process will be over.
Adding a condition to check whether the variable `self._psml_structure` is `None` is helpful to this bug, as the following:
```python
if self._parse_summaries and self._psml_structure is None:
```
Because the return type of the `psml_structure_from_xml` method is `list`, it should be explicitly indicated whether the variable `self._psml_structure` is `None`.

issue.title: `apply_on_packets` not terminating after `packet_count`
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When using `apply_on_packets` with `packet_count` specified, the capture does not terminate despite the packet count being met. Setting the `timeout` together with the `packet_count` parameter does not terminate the capture either. (`timeout` parameter works well on its own when `packet_count` is not specified)

This is my debug log:

```
2023-09-27 11:24:51,283 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Creating Dumpcap subprocess with parameters: /usr/bin/dumpcap -q -i enp0s8 -w -
2023-09-27 11:24:51,288 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Dumpcap subprocess (pid 35040) created
2023-09-27 11:24:51,584 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Creating TShark subprocess with parameters: /usr/bin/tshark -l -n -T pdml -c 5  -w /tmp/mitm-output.pcap -i -
2023-09-27 11:24:51,585 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Executable: /usr/bin/tshark
2023-09-27 11:24:51,588 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Capturing on 'enp0s8'
2023-09-27 11:24:51,589 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - File: -
2023-09-27 11:24:51,590 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - TShark subprocess (pid 35059) created
2023-09-27 11:24:51,590 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Starting to go through packets
2023-09-27 11:24:51,623 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Running as user "root" and group "root". This could be dangerous.
2023-09-27 11:24:51,922 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Capturing on '-'
2023-09-27 11:24:51,937 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - ** (tshark:35059) 11:24:51.935238 [Main MESSAGE] -- Capture started.
2023-09-27 11:24:51,938 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - ** (tshark:35059) 11:24:51.935277 [Main MESSAGE] -- File: "/tmp/mitm-output.pcap"
2023-09-27 11:24:52,238 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Cleanup Subprocess (pid 35059)
2023-09-27 11:24:52,240 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - 5 packets captured
Unknown child process pid 35059, will report returncode 255
2023-09-27 11:24:52,246 - LiveCapture - DEBUG - Cleanup Subprocess (pid 35040)
```

My guess is that the underlying tshark process is being terminated before pyshark is able to perform any cleanups. This results in the event loop failing to terminate properly and continuously resets itself.

**To Reproduce**
Simply create a python3 script that uses `LiveCapture` and use `apply_on_packets`.

```python3
capture = pyshark.LiveCapture(
        interface="enp0s8",
        output_file="/tmp/mitm-output.pcap",
        debug=True,
    )

capture.apply_on_packets(
        lambda packet : print(packet),
        timeout=5,
        packet_count=5,
    )
```

**Expected behavior**
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.

I

**Versions (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: ubuntu@22.04
 - pyshark version: 0.6
 - python version: 3.7.9
 - tshark version: 3.6.2 (Git v3.6.2 packaged as 3.6.2-2)

comment.body: I tested this with `sniff_continuously` as well and the same problem exists there as well.
